syscore package¶

Submodules¶

syscore.algos module¶

Algos.py

Basic building blocks of trading rules, like volatility measurement and crossovers

syscore.algos.robust_vol_calc(x, days=35, min_periods=10, vol_abs_min=1e-10, vol_floor=True, floor_min_quant=0.05, floor_min_periods=100, floor_days=500)¶

Robust exponential volatility calculation, assuming daily series of prices We apply an absolute minimum level of vol (absmin)

and a volfloor based on lowest vol over recent history
Parameters:
  • days (int) – Number of days in lookback (default 35)
  • min_periods (int) – The minimum number of observations (default 10)
  • vol_abs_min – The size of absolute minimum (default =0.0000000001) 0.0= not used

:param vol_floor Apply a floor to volatility (default True) :type vol_floor: bool :param floor_min_quant: The quantile to use for volatility floor (eg 0.05 means we use 5% vol) (default 0.05) :type floor_min_quant: float :param floor_days: The lookback for calculating volatility floor, in days (*default 500) :type floor_days: int :param floor_min_periods: Minimum observations for floor - until reached floor is zero (default 100) :type floor_min_periods: int

Returns:pd.DataFrame – volatility measure

syscore.dateutils module¶

Various routines to do with dates

syscore.dateutils.expiry_date(expiry_ident)¶

Translates an expiry date which could be “20150305” or “201505” into a datetime

Parameters:expiry_ident – Expiry to be processed
Returns:datetime.datetime or datetime.date 
>>> expiry_date('201503')
datetime.datetime(2015, 3, 1, 0, 0)

>>> expiry_date('20150305')
datetime.datetime(2015, 3, 5, 0, 0)

>>> expiry_date(datetime.datetime(2015,5,1))
datetime.datetime(2015, 5, 1, 0, 0)
syscore.dateutils.expiry_diff(carry_row, floor_date_diff=20)¶

Given a pandas row containing CARRY_CONTRACT and PRICE_CONTRACT, both of which represent dates

Return the annualised difference between the dates

Parameters:
  • carry_row (pandas row, or something that quacks like it) – object with attributes CARRY_CONTRACT and PRICE_CONTRACT
  • floor_date_diff – If date resolves to less than this, floor here (default 20)
Returns:

datetime.datetime or datetime.date

syscore.fileutils module¶

syscore.fileutils.get_pathname_for_package(package_name, paths_or_files=[])¶

Returns the filename of part of a package

Parameters:
  • package_name – Name of python package
  • path – Subdirectory within
Returns:

full pathname of package

 
>>> get_pathname_for_package("syscore", ["fileutils.py"])
'/home/rob/workspace3/newengine/syscore/fileutils.py'

>>> get_pathname_for_package("syscore")
'/home/rob/workspace3/newengine/syscore'

>>> get_pathname_for_package("syscore", ["tests","pricetestdata.csv"])
'/home/rob/workspace3/newengine/syscore/tests/pricetestdata.csv'

syscore.genutils module¶

Utilities I can’t put anywhere else...

syscore.genutils.sign(x)¶

Return the sign of x (float or int) :param x: Thing we want sign of :type x: int, float

Returns:1 or -1 
>>> sign(3)
1.0

>>> sign(3.0)
1.0

>>> sign(-3)
-1.0

>>> sign(0)
1.0
syscore.genutils.str_of_int(x)¶

Returns the string of int of x, handling nan’s or whatever

Parameters:x (int or float) – Name of python package
Returns:1.0 or -1.0 
>>> str_of_int(34)
'34'

>>> str_of_int(34.0)
'34'

>>> import numpy as np
>>> str_of_int(np.nan)
''

syscore.objects module¶

Do fun things with objects and classes

syscore.objects.calc_or_cache(some_object, dictname, keyname, func, *args, **kwargs)¶

Assumes that some_object has an attribute dictname, and that is a dict

If dictname[keyname] exists return it. Else call func with *args and **kwargs if the latter updates the dictionary

Used for cache within various kinds of objects like config, price, data, system...

Parameters:
  • some_object (object) – The object with object.dictname
  • dictname (str) – attribute of object containing a dict
  • keyname (valid dict key) – keyname to look for in dict
  • func (function) – function to call if keyname missing. will take some_object and keyname as first two args
  • kwargs (args,) – also passed to fun if called
Returns:

contents of dict or result of calling function
syscore.objects.calc_or_cache_nested(some_object, dictname, keyname1, keyname2, func, *args, **kwargs)¶

Assumes that some_object has an attribute dictname, and that is a nested dict

If dictname[keyname1][keyname2] exists return it. Else call func with arguments: some_object, keyname1, keyname2, *args and **kwargs if we have to call the func updates the dictionary with it’s value

Used for cache within various kinds of objects like config, price, data, system...

Parameters:
  • some_object (object) – The object with object.dictname
  • dictname (str) – attribute of object containing a dict
  • keyname1 (valid dict key) – keyname to look for in dict
  • keyname2 (valid dict key) – keyname to look for in nested dict
  • func (function) – function to call if keyname missing. will take some_object and keyname1, keyname2 as first three args
  • kwargs (args,) – also passed to fun if called
Returns:

contents of dict or result of calling function
syscore.objects.hasallattr(some_object, attrlist=[])¶

Check something has all the attributes you need

Parameters:
  • some_object (object) – The object with attributes to test
  • attrlist (list of str) – Attributes to check
Returns:

bool

 
>>> from sysdata.data import Data
>>> data=Data()
>>> setattr(data, "one", 1)
>>> setattr(data, "two", 2)
>>> hasallattr(data, ["one", "two"])
True

>>> hasallattr(data, ["one", "two","three"])
False
syscore.objects.resolve_data_method(some_object, data_string)¶

eg if data_string=”data1.data2.method” then returns the method some_object.data1.data2.method

Parameters:
  • some_object (object) – The object with a method
  • data_string (str) – method or attribute within object
Returns:

method in some_object

 
>>> from sysdata.data import Data
>>>
>>> data=Data()
>>> resolve_data_method(data, "get_instrument_price")
<bound method Data.get_instrument_price of Data object with 0 instruments>
>>>
>>> meta_data=Data()
>>> setattr(meta_data, "meta", data)
>>> resolve_data_method(meta_data, "meta.get_instrument_price")
<bound method Data.get_instrument_price of Data object with 0 instruments>
>>> 
>>> meta_meta_data=Data()
>>> setattr(meta_meta_data, "moremeta", meta_data)
>>> resolve_data_method(meta_meta_data, "moremeta.meta.get_instrument_price")
<bound method Data.get_instrument_price of Data object with 0 instruments>
syscore.objects.resolve_function(func_or_func_name)¶

if func_or_func_name is a callable function, then return the function

If it is a string containing ‘.’ then it is a function in a module, return the function

Parameters:func_or_func_name (int, float, or something else eg np.nan) – Name of a function including package.module, or a callable function
Returns:function 
>>> resolve_function(str)
<class 'str'>

>>> resolve_function("syscore.algos.robust_vol_calc")
<function robust_vol_calc at 0xb70077c4>
syscore.objects.update_recalc(subsystem_object, additional_delete_on_recalc=[], additional_dont_delete=[])¶

Update the recalculation dictionaries

FIXME - is this actually used??

(see system.basesystem and subsystem)

Parameters:
  • subsystem_object (object) – The subsystem object with attributes to test
  • additional_delete_on_recalc (list of str) – Things to add to this attribute
  • additional_dont_delete (list of str) – Things to add to this attribute
Returns:

None (changes subsystem_object)

syscore.pdutils module¶

Utilities to help with pandas

syscore.pdutils.apply_cap(pd_dataframe, capvalue)¶

Applies a cap to the values in a Tx1 pandas dataframe

Parameters:
  • pd_dataframe (pd.DataFrame) – Tx1 pandas data frame
  • capvalue – Maximum absolute value allowed
Returns:

pd.DataFrame Tx1

 
>>> x=pd.DataFrame(dict(a=[2.0, 7.0, -7.0, -6.99]), pd.date_range(pd.datetime(2015,1,1), periods=4))
>>> apply_cap(x, 5.0)
            0
2015-01-01  2
2015-01-02  5
2015-01-03 -5
2015-01-04 -5
syscore.pdutils.divide_df(x, y)¶

Divide Tx1 dataframe by Tx1 dataframe

Parameters:
  • x (pd.DataFrame) – Tx1 pandas data frame
  • y (pd.DataFrame) – Tx1 pandas data frame
Returns:

pd.DataFrame Tx1

 
>>> x=pd.DataFrame(dict(a=[2.0, 7.0, -7.0, -7.00]), pd.date_range(pd.datetime(2015,1,1), periods=4))
>>> y=pd.DataFrame(dict(b=[2.0, 3.5, 2.0, -3.5]), pd.date_range(pd.datetime(2015,1,1), periods=4))
a

2015-01-01 1.0 2015-01-02 2.0 2015-01-03 -3.5 2015-01-04 2.0

syscore.pdutils.pd_readcsv(filename, date_index_name='DATETIME')¶

Reads a pandas data frame, with time index labelled package_name(/path1/path2.., filename

Parameters:
  • filename (str) – Filename with extension
  • date_index_name (list of str) – Column name of date index
Returns:

pd.DataFrame

 
>>> pd.read_csv("tests/pricetestdata.csv").tail(1)
                ADJ
2015-04-22  159.225
syscore.pdutils.pd_readcsv_frompackage(package_name, filename, path=[''])¶

Run pd_readcsv on a file in python with optional paths eg path=[‘path’,path2’, ...] package_name(/path1/path2.., filename

Parameters:
  • package_name (str) – Name of a package eg syscore that contains
  • filename (str) – Filename with extension
  • path (list of str) – List of paths to complete full path structure
Returns:

pd.DataFrame

 
>>> pd_readcsv_frompackage("syscore", "pricetestdata.csv", path=["tests"]).tail(1)
                ADJ
2015-04-22  159.225
